awd_titl_txt: REU Site: Research In Neutrino Astrophysics at the University of Wisconsin-River Falls
awd_abstract_narration:
This award supports the Research Experiences for Undergraduates (REU) site in neutrino astrophysics at the University of Wisconsin-River Falls (UWRF). Six undergraduate students per year will participate in ten weeks of summer research on projects with the IceCube Neutrino Observatory or South Pole neutron monitors. Students will be integrated into a research collaboration that opened the field of neutrino astronomy, and work in a department where learning and involving undergraduates in research are priorities. Students will acquire a broad range of research skills, will appreciate the value of fundamental science to society, and will be mentored on giving effective scientific presentations and in communicating science. To broaden dissemination to enhance scientific and technological understanding they will also be expected to give a presentation on their summer work, and participate in outreach activates, including presentations at the UWRF Upward Bound program. Benefits to society will occur when REU students apply the skills they acquire in computer programming, data mining and simulations to their STEM area of interest in their respective careers. 

Students will choose from research topics including neutrino astrophysics, cosmic rays, particle physics, and neutron monitor physics. Students will make contributions to the IceCube experiment that will help advance understanding and knowledge in the field of neutrino astronomy. IceCube is a unique telescope located at the South Pole which looks at the universe via neutrinos. Some students will work on projects involving the South Pole neutron monitors. These monitors observe low energy cosmic rays and monitor solar activity. With access to IceCube's data or data from the South Pole monitors, high performance computing resources, and personnel, students will make real contributions while acquiring research skills that are transferrable to many fields of science, technology, and engineering.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Neutrino astronomy, a new window to the universe, has been pioneered by IceCube through, for example, the observation of a diffuse astrophysical flux of neutrinos and the identification of a very high energy neutrino candidate from an identified extraterrestrial source. Neutrinos are among the fundamental particles of nature, and they can travel in undeflected paths across vast distances between galaxies. Hence, they are ideal cosmic messengers. Beyond neutrino astrophysics, the IceCube Neutrino Observatory, deployed deep in the glacial ice at the South Pole, is also addressing questions on fundamental properties of neutrinos. Also deployed at the South Pole are two smaller detectors, neutron monitors, which observe the lowest energy cosmic rays, and are sensitive to variations in the rates at which they arrive at Earth due to solar activity. The intellectual merit of both of these experiments has been acknowledged by the community. Participating in research in astrophysics, astronomy, and cosmic rays could inspire this generation of undergraduates to stay in the field and pursue science at the next level.

At the University of Wisconsin-River Falls REU Site in Neutrino Astrophysics we had, in the four years of the project, 15 undergraduate participants working on a wide variety of research projects in neutrino astrophysics connected with the IceCube Neutrino Observatory. Some students worked on projects related to the neutron monitors at the South Pole. REU participants came from a variety of types of institutions across the nation, including large research universities, and four and two-year colleges. Diversity and broadening participation in physics is a priority at the UWRF REU Site. Continuing support of REU participants by mentors, with letters for graduate school and fellowship applications continue to occur years after students have participated.

Training is a big component of the program. REU participants working on IceCube acquire skills in analyzing large data sets and in complex simulations, both done using high performance computing. To get them up to speed with programming and data analysis, each year they attended a week-long astrophysics bootcamp at the Wisconsin IceCube Particle Astrophysics Center in Madison, WI. This bootcamp is a key component of the training aspect of the REU site.  Participants learned python programming, statistical methods in data analysis, and how to use the high-performance computing resources of IceCube. The bootcamps were virtual in the last two years the REU program operated, and the REU program in 2021 was virtual. However, participants were given the opportunity later in the year to travel to UWRF to present their work at the UWRF Fall Research Gala. All of the participants from the virtual program visited UWRF and presented posters of their work.

Each summer participants attended workshops on scientific writing and poster presentations, the graduate school application process and GRE preparation, communicating science, and on research methods and resources in physics. Social activities available to participants include field trips to state parks, kayaking, group dinners, and dinners at mentors? homes. For the virtual program participants had online game nights. For the in-person programs before the pandemic, each year?s cohort visited students at the UWRF Upward Bound program, where they described their backgrounds, and the path they took from high school to college physics.

UWRF?s involvement in the neutron monitor research continues to provide a unique opportunity for undergraduates to deploy and conduct research at the South Pole. REU participants are included in the pool of students from which we select students for the South Pole. In 2019 one REU participant traveled to the South Pole, under a separate award, for work on the South Pole Neutron Monitors.
